clean_story:
"Focused work. Distraction’s enemy. Dopamine’s hidden cost. "

"Dopamine" is the brain’s reward chemical—like a gold coin for doing something fun.
"Default Mode Network" (DMN) is your brain’s daydreaming system—active when you’re bored or scrolling.
"Deep work" means concentrating without interruption, like building a Lego castle without stopping.

Social media, games, and notifications hijack dopamine—giving tiny rewards for checking your phone.
This trains your brain to crave quick hits instead of long focus.
The DMN wakes up when you’re distracted, pulling you into autopilot thoughts.

Deep work shuts down the DMN—like closing background apps on a slow computer.
Example: A writer drafting a chapter without email checks finishes 3x faster.
Studies show 90-minute focused sessions (no distractions) boost learning and creativity.

Trick your brain: Schedule deep work like a meeting.
Turn off notifications.
Use a timer (try 25-minute "Pomodoro" sprints).

Three related subjects are attention span economics, flow state triggers, and digital minimalism hacks.
